bestBHT.bht: The address and greeting in this verse emphasizes the close relationship believers have with God as their Father. The inclusion of our further emphasizes this endearing connection. This address is similar to the one in 1 Thessalonians 1:1, with the addition of our after Father. By referring to believers as Church in God and Christ, it signifies that they are not simply a gathered group, but a work and building of both the Father and Christ. As part of this Church, believers are adopted by God and regenerated in Christ.

Henry Alford: ADDRESS AND GREETING. On ver. 1, see 1 Thess. i. 1, note.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: more endearing than the address, :- "in God THE
Albert Barnes: Paul, and Silvanus, and Timotheus; - See the notes on 1 Thessalonians 1:1.
John Calvin: By a Church in God and Christ is meant one that has not merely been gathered together under the banner of faith, but is the work and building of the Father as well as of Christ."
...because while God adopts us to himself, and regenerates us, we from him begin to be in Christ.
Archibald T. Robertson: Paul, etc. (Παυλοσ, ετχ.). This address or superscription is identical with that in 1 Thessalonians 1:1 save that our (ημων) is added after

bhtAttempts.bht: The address and greeting in this verse emphasizes the close relationship believers have with God as their Father. The inclusion of our further emphasizes this endearing connection. This address is similar to the one in 1 Thessalonians 1:1, with the addition of our after Father. By referring to believers as Church in God and Christ, it signifies that they are not simply a gathered group, but a work and building of both the Father and Christ. As part of this Church, believers are adopted by God and regenerated in Christ.

This address and greeting in 2 Thessalonians 1:1 highlights the intimate bond between believers and God as their Father. Adding our emphasizes this affectionate connection. The phrase Church in God and Christ conveys that believers are not just a gathered group, but a work fashioned by both the Father and Christ. This signifies the adoption and regeneration of believers in Christ. The wording of this address is similar to the one found in 1 Thessalonians 1:1, affirming the unity of Paul, Silvanus, and Timotheus.

The greeting in this passage underscores the intimate relationship between believers and God as their Father. The inclusion of our emphasizes this affectionate connection. Referring to believers as the Church in God and Christ reveals that they are not merely a gathered group, but a work and building of both the Father and Christ. This speaks to the concept of believers being adopted and regenerated by God in Christ. The address is similar to the one in another letter where Paul, Silvanus, and Timotheus are mentioned, highlighting their unity.

The greeting in this verse highlights the close bond between believers and God as their Father. Our is added to further emphasize this endearing connection. Describing believers as the Church in God and Christ suggests that they are not simply a gathered group, but a work created by both the Father and Christ. This signifies the adoption and regeneration of believers in Christ. The address is similar to another letter where Paul, Silvanus, and Timotheus are mentioned, emphasizing their unity.

The greeting in this verse emphasizes the intimate bond between believers and God as their Father. The addition of our further underscores this affectionate connection. By referring to believers as the Church in God and Christ, it conveys that they are more than just a gathered group but a work reliant on both the Father and Christ. This highlights the concept of believers being adopted and regenerated by God in Christ. The address resembles one found in another letter that mentions Paul, Silvanus, and Timotheus, reinforcing their unity.
